1.content:
My name is Sam. According to my adoptive mother, my parents died in a car accident, and left me in the custody of her, their babysitter. But then, she also insisted I was a boy.

Now, I want to be clear: I am not trans, and nobody claimed that I was trans. For eight years, she told me I was a boy, even though I was a girl.

I was six when my best friend, John Scooter, told me the truth: I was finishing up in the bathroom when he walked in on me. He took one look at me and said, "Sam,... You're a girl."

And it was like a light went on. I knew why I was interested in girl's clothing, and why I wanted to wear my hair long.

Unfortunately, when I went home and told Ma Stone about it, she just said John was playing a trick on me. "Of course you're a boy, Sam. Don't you think I would know if you weren't?"

******************************


It was the summer I turned 11 when everything changed.

It was August, about a month before the start of school. A bunch of us decided to play baseball in the vacant lot next to Ravenscroft Academy, an exclusive school down the road from us. Scooter had been accepted there, but said he wasn't allowed to tell us much about it. Okay, Scooter, I thought, two can play that game. You can just wait until I ask Ma Stone if she believes I'm a girl, or if she thinks I'm a boy who needs a training bra.

Now, I was plenty girly, but I loved playing baseball. I took a swing at one of Scooter's pitches, and knocked it out of the park,... or, in this case, over the wall and onto the grounds of Ravenscroft.

"I'll get it," Scooter said.

"No," I replied, "I hit the ball, I should go get it."

"They'll let me in, I'm going there."

"But I'm faster," I said, and ran to the gate.

I pressed the intercom button, and a woman came on the screen. "May I help you?"

"Uh, hi, my name's Sam. I hit a baseball over the fence, sorry. Can I come get it? Or can you bring it to the gate? Please?"

The woman leaned closer to the camera, presumably to get a closer look at me on the screen. "You said your name is Sam? Samuel?"

"Actually, I'm a Samantha, but my adoptive mother won't admit it. Could you buzz me in?"

She reacted when I said I was Samantha. "Remain at the gate, Samantha. Wardwell will escort you."

I don't know what I expected, but it wasn't who showed up at the gate. Wardwell was a mountain of a man. If you told me he was so much as an inch under seven and a half feet tall, I'd have told you to double-check your tape measure. And yet, something about him seemed so... familiar.

He looked down at me and smiled. "Samantha?"

"Wardwell?"

He opened the gate for me. "Follow me, little missy."

As I entered, Wardwell threw the ball to the boys.

I followed Wardwell to a large building, flanked by four smaller buildings. In we went, then up the stairs, then down a hall toward two offices next to each other. A plaque on one identified it as the office of HEATHER GARDNER, MAGISTRA, with the other claimed by DANIEL COCHRANE, MAGISTER. Wardwell knocked on Ms. Gardner's door, and said, "Here she is."

The door opened. "Come in, Samantha. There is someone here who you should meet."

I entered. Seated at the desk was a middle-aged woman, no doubt Ms. Gardner.

Also in the room was a woman in her mid-twenties. She turned as I approached, and I saw her face. It was a face I'd seen in my dreams many times. A face a little like the face I saw in the mirror. Could it be... ?

"M-Mommy?"

She knelt before me. "Samantha?"

We hugged as if we would be separated again if we let go.
1.title: Who I Am

11.content:
"I was told you died," I said to my mother.

"I didn't know what to think," Mom replied. "Nobody knew where you were." She broke the hug to look at me. "Why is your hair so short?"

"Ma Stone insisted that I was a boy."

" When you're looking for a girl," Ms. Gardner said, "you don't look twice at a boy. She needed you to play the part of a boy, perhaps until she forgot why." She took out a wand and pointed it at me. A bright light shot out of it.

When the light faded, I had long hair. "It's magic!"

"Indeed it is, Samantha. Ravenscroft is no cowan school, but a school for witches. Both your parents learned magick here, and so will you. Now, is there anything else you'd like?"

I didn't have to think twice. "A training bra."

"Done." Another flash, and I could feel the bra on my skin. "Vanessa, why don't you take Samantha to your office? Introduce her to Maddalena? Get your husband on the phone, and let Samantha talk to her father?"

"Of course, Magistra. Come, Samantha."

As we walked, I asked, "Who's Maddalena? Do I have a little sister?"

"No, Sam. Maddalena is my familiar. She helps me with my magick."
11.title: Continue

111.content:
Mom led me to her office and opened the door. We were immediately greeted by the most adorable black cat. "Maddalena," Mom said, "this is my daughter, Samantha. Sam, this is Maddalena."

I started petting Maddalena. "So a familiar is a pet?"

At that, Maddalena swatted my nose. *Manners!* said a voice in my head. Then, Maddalena flashed her claws at me, as if to warn me about my choice of words next time.

"A familiar is much more than a pet," Mom said. "They lend their magick to us, and their lives are extended in return. You might consider an apology."

"I'm sorry, Maddalena. I didn't know."

*All is forgiven,* she replied. *Welcome back to the family. They've been worried about you.*

Mom picked up the phone and dialed. "David? No, darling, nothing's wrong. There's someone who wishes to speak with you." She handed the phone to me.

I cleared my throat. "Hello?"

"Hello," the man on the phone said. "Who's this?"

"Samantha. Samantha... Procter."

"Sam? It's you? Thank the Goddess you're alright! You are alright, aren't you? I'm your father."

I smiled. "I'm fine, Daddy. Much better, now that I'm with you and Mom again."

"I'll be over as soon as I'm off work. Think of what you'd like to do, because I want to do it all with you."

"I'd like that, too, Daddy."

There was a knock on the door. When Mom answered it, it was the woman who spoke to me over the intercom. "The Magistra sent me. There's a woman named Anna Stone in her office, and she's displeased."

I stiffened. Ma Stone was here.

"Thank you, Mrs. Jennings," Mom said, "we'll be right there." She wrapped an arm around me. "Have no fear, Sam. All will be put right." Then, she picked up her wand. "We'll just see what happens when her displeasure meets my righteous anger."
111.title: My Family

1111.content:
I stayed behind Mom's dress as we returned to the magistra's office.

Ma Stone was there, and she wasn't happy. "I won't stand for any more of your delays," she said. "My son's friends say he was brought into this building, and I want him back now!"

Magistra Gardner looked at Ma Stone as dispassionately as if she had asked for a cup of coffee. "There are two problems with what you're asking, Ms. Stone: You have no children, and Samantha is no one's son."

"What are you talking about?"

"You've been found out, Anna," Mom said. "Dressing Sam as a boy worked for a while, but you had to know it wouldn't last forever. Or did you honestly forget that part?"

"Mrs. Procter!" Ma Stone said. "Fancy meeting you here... It's been so... How have you been?"

"I'm better now, thanks for asking. As you can see, my daughter is with me again. My husband and I may have been younger than you would have liked, but that wasn't a decision you had a right to make."

"It wasn't fair," Ma Stone said, defeat in her voice. "I wanted a child. Why couldn't I have one, while two fifteen-year-olds could?"

"That doesn't sound fair," Mom said. "But neither was stealing eight years of my daughter's life from me. Nor was making her live as a boy for so long that you couldn't think of her any other way."

Two police officers entered. I didn't know who had called them, but Ma Stone didn't want to see them now. "What are you going to do now?" she asked.

"I don't think this needs to concern the police," Mom said. "I believe we will settle this... our way."

Mom and the magistra nodded, then pointed their wands at Ma Stone. There was a burst of light.

When my vision cleared, there was an 11-year-old boy where Ma Stone had stood.
1111.title: Confrontation Between Mother Figures

11112.content:
Magistra Gardner pressed a button on her desk intercom. "Wardwell, could you please come to my office." Politely, she said. "We have a young man who is ready for his orientation."

"I am on my way." Courtly, a deep male voice replied.

Moments later, the towering figure of Wardwell entered the office. The former Anna Stone trembled at the sight of him. Behind him, I noticed a petite, doll-like girl, who shyly smiled and waved as she caught my eye.

"I had just finished giving my daughter, Tia, her orientation." Politely, Wardwell said. He then eyed the young man cringing before him. "I take it... Mr. Stone will be attending school here."

Mom nodded. "He has much to learn." Firmly, she replied. "Please take him to orientations."

Wardwell turned to Tia. "Stay here until I can come for you." Kindly, he said. "I shall only be but a moment or two."

The small girl, Tia, nodded, as Wardwell then took the boy by the arms and carried him out, kicking and screaming.

It seemed appropriate to me. For eight years, she had tried to make me think I was a boy. Now, she actually was one.
11112.title: Apt Punishment

111121.content:
After Wardwell had left, Mom smiled at Tia. "This is Samantha, my lost daughter." Kindly, she explained. "The upset boy who was carried out was her kidnapper." She then turned to me. "This is Tia, Wardwell's adopted daughter."

"Hi..." Shyly, Tia said.

"She's a bit shy..." Worried, I said.

"She has had it rough, honey." Patiently, Mom explained. "Give her time to get to know you."

"I had lived at Child Hope orphanage since I was around two." Softly, Tia said. "They... were not so good to me. Maddalena came to my rescue a few short days ago, and brought me here, where my new dad, Wardwell, took me in and adopted me."

"I was kidnapped around the same age, and treated like a boy for the longest time." Tearing up, I said. "It was a high flying ball that brought me back to my family."

"I guess luck was on both our sides." Smiling slightly, Tia said.

"I guess..." Giggling, I replied.

Tia giggled back just as Wardwell entered the Magistra's office. "I see you have already made a new friend." Kindly, he said. "Perhaps you will share a few classes together."

Tia smiled. "I would like that." Calmly, she said.

"As would I." Smiling, I added.

"Well, I must be off so to purchase what Tia will need for her classes." Calmly, he said. "Welcome to Ravenscroft school, Miss Procter."

I smiled and nodded before Wardwell led Tia out. Once they were gone, Mom turned to Magistra Gardner. "We must be off as well, to purchase supplies and reunite her with her father."

Gardner nodded. "Blessed be."
111121.title: Meeting Tia Wardwell.

choices: The Other Students Come to Ravenscroft
1111211.content:
School supplies at Ravenscroft were not like those at public school. I mean, where else would a pentacle necklace be required? Plus, at Ravenscroft, nothing was promoted as being bulletproof.

Mom and I had just left the school store when a familiar voice said, "There she is!"

"Daddy!" I ran right over and wrapped my arms around him, and he did the same to me. Neither one of us was in a hurry to let go, as tears of joy flowed freely.

When we finally ended the embrace, and we had composed ourselves, I asked, "What do you do, Daddy?"

"I work in the local school system," he replied. "It's my duty to give advance notice of things like accreditation teams coming to inspect Ravenscroft, so the teachers can put their glamours up."

"Glamours?"

"It wouldn't do for cowan eyes to see what goes on at a school for witches, now, would it?"

"And cowans are people who aren't witches, right?"

"Almost right," Mom said. "The word cowan is both singular and plural."

"I was a good student in public school," I told my parents. "I hope I'll be able to make you proud here."

"You're here, now, Sam," Dad said. "Your mother and I couldn't possibly be any prouder."
1111211.title: Reuniting with dad.

11112112.content:
The day came for school to begin, and the other students arrived. Most took a bus to Ravenscroft, but one, I knew, walked through the open gate. "Scooter!" I called, giving him a hug.

"Sam?" he replied. "I almost didn't recognize you, with long hair and a dress."

"This is the real me," I said, twirling around. "I never have to pretend I'm a boy again."

"And now you know why I couldn't tell you anything about Ravenscroft."

******************************


The first order of business was to be sorted into one of the residence halls. Athame Hall and Wand Hall were for the boys, while Cauldron Hall and Chalice Hall were for the girls.

There was something interesting that happened during this sorting process. I wasn't aware of what started it, but one of the first-years and one of the seventh-years over in the boys' line started arguing. The argument ended when the seventh-year drew his wand and changed the first-year boy into a girl. Wardwell calmly pulled her out of the boys' line and put her into the girls' line. The only explanation I heard was that the first-year boy tried to start a prank war with the seventh-year boy.

Tia and I were both assigned to Chalice Hall. In fact, we were assigned to be roommates. "We are going to have such fun together, Tia," I said.

"At least for a while," she replied.

"What do you mean?"

"Dr. Willard checked me out. He said there were two kinds of kids at my height: some stay little, while others grow big. Dad was one of the latter, and I am, too."

"Well," I said, "I, for one, am looking forward to seeing you grow into the woman you should be."

"Dad is, too. He was horrified when I told him the kids at the orphanage used to put me in a dresser drawer."

"Is that so? Well, here's hoping that each and every one of those kids gets everything they deserve, and that you get to watch it happen."
11112112.title: The Other Students Come to Ravenscroft

111121121.content:
The next morning, classes began.

"Good morning, students," our first teacher said. "My name is Professor Burroughs. I am your Spells and Incantations teacher. Spells and incantations are at the heart of directing magick." He looked at me. "Miss Procter, would you step forward, please?"

Not knowing what to expect, I approached him.

Pulling out his wand, Professor Burroughs touched my throat and muttered something. When he finished, he asked, "How do you feel, Miss Procter?"

I wanted to say "I feel fine, Professor," but what came out was "Spider-Man belch out, Hoverboard."

"A simple aphasia spell," he explained. "Under it, you are unable to communicate." Addressing the class, he said, "Be advised, all teachers are protected by charms that turn spells directed against us back upon the one casting the spell. If you cast an aphasia spell against us, you will feel its effects, and you will find it exceedingly difficult to cast the spell to counter it. Which reminds me." He touched my throat with his wand again and said something else. "And now how do you feel?"

I spoke cautiously, uncertain what might come out of my mouth this time. "Better? Better."
111121121.title: Our First Class

1111211211.content:
As Tia and I left our first class, I spotted a first-year girl talking to Mom down the hall from us. I could not hear what was being said, but the girl was clearly upset about something. She had been crying, and she occasionally stomped a single foot to emphasize her frustrations. Mom kept a calm expression as she talked to the girl before sending her on her way. Curious, I walked up, with Tia following. "Did something happen to her?" Wincing, I asked.

Mom gave a patient smile. "That was Cire Child." Calmly, she explained. "She was a boy until she got pranked by one of the seventh-years during orientation."

"But pranks during official school functions are forbidden." Worried, Tia said.

Mom nodded. "The seventh-year girl would have been reprimanded for her actions, had Cire had not counter-pranked her." Remaining calm, Mom replied. "You see, magick duels and prank wars are strictly forbidden between first and seventh years, so we had to punish them both."

"What was their punishment?" Curious, I asked.

"Cire is surprisingly talented for her age." Smiling, Mom explained. "She returned the favor, turning the seventh year girl into a boy, thus beginning the magick duel." Her smile vanished. "Now they both must finish this year as the opposite gender, to remind them there are laws to the use of magick."

"I think we just got a lecture..." Wincing, Tia said.

Mom smiled. "Blessed be, girls."
1111211211.title: Continue

11112112112.content:
After morning classes, it was time for lunch. Tia and I got our trays and went looking for a table, until I saw Scooter sitting alone. "May we join you?"

"Be my guests," he replied.

As we sat down, I said, "Tia, this is John Scooter, my best friend for years. Scooter, this is Tia Wardwell, my new roommate."

"Pleased to meet you, Tia," Scooter said, offering his hand.

"Any friend of Sam's is a friend of mine," Tia said, accepting it.

"Is this a private party," asked a new voice, "or can anyone sit in?"

"Go ahead, stranger. The girls are Samantha and Tia. Everybody calls me Scooter."

"Cire Child. It's insanely hard to find your place when you're in the wrong body."

"Oh," Scooter said, "you're the one who tried to start a... what did they call it?... a prank war?"

"I call it defending myself. And now the guidance counselor says I have to stay this way for the whole school year." She snorted. "She's probably just too dumb to figure out how to do it."

"You might want to walk that back, Cire."

"Why?"

"Because the woman you just called dumb? I call her Mom."

A school prefect stopped at the table. "Did I hear someone badmouthing Mrs. Procter?"

"What's it to you?" Cire asked.

"To me? Not much. But you should definitely be worried about her. She didn't get a reputation as the Queen of Pranks by just sipping tea. I knew one girl who tried her? For a month, whenever Wardwell's hounds got too close, she turned into a cat. Would you like to see if Fancy Feast is as good as the commercials say?"

Cire took a breath. "Perhaps... I spoke hastily."
11112112112.title: Meeting Cire Child.

111121121121.content:
"Queen of pranks...?" Worried, I asked. "My mom, really?"

The school prefect nodded. "When you went missing, Mrs Procter went on a crusade to make all pranks fair, as any first year student could have been you returning to her."

"What's so fair about being in the wrong body for a year?" Pouting, Cire demanded.

"Ah, you are the first-year who counter-pranked Miss, or rather, Mr Cohan." Bemused, the school prefect said. "Take comfort in knowing that the seventh-year student is not enjoying his situation any better."

With that said, the school prefect walked on. Cire, however, still seemed depressed. "I can still hear my little sister laughing at me, all the way back home."

"Um,... My dad told me that, when life hands you something, make it your own." Softly, Tia said. "I think this applies here."

"Sure it does." Smiling, I said. "You are a girl for the year, so make the experience your own, something you can use to your advantage when you become a boy again."

"What do you mean...?" Confused, Cire asked.

"I was forced to live the life of a boy since I was kidnapped." Serious, I replied. "Now that I am with my family, I have to get used to the life of a girl again."

"What- What's the point?" Shaking her head, Cire asked.

"Having lived the life of a boy for so long, I have a far better understanding of how they tick than most girls on campus." Smiling, I said. "Do you have any idea what some boys would pay to know how girls tick?"

"That's right." Catching on, Tia said. "By being a girl, you get first hand knowledge of how and why girls do what they do."

"You two are scaring me...." Slouching, Cire said.

"Sit up straight, young lady." Imitating my mom, I scolded. "It's bad posture, and it will cost you back pain later."

Cire sighed, sitting up right. "It's not comfortable."

"No pain, no gain." Smiling, Tia said. "Good posture strengthens the back."

"I take it you two want to teach me how to be a proper girl..." Wincing, Cire said.

"Not a proper girl, so much." Smiling, I said. "Still, if I can survive having to act like a boy, you can survive acting like a girl."

"That, and we'll help you." Kindly, Tia said. She shrugged. "What do you have to lose?"

Cire sighed. "Fine..."

Tia and I smiled, before our conversation moved to the importance of a girl keeping her legs closer together than a boy, proper stance, and so on.

Unknown to me until later, Mom was watching from a distance with a warm smile on her face. I guess she had a feeling that Tia and I would be a good influence on her as, that night, we found that she had been bunked with us.
111121121121.title: My Mother, Queen of Pranks?

1111211211212.content:
Fortunately, it was only a half day for classes, to give the first-year students time to digest the pranks from the seventh-years. I was relieved to know that the pranks were not a tradition held lightly. They were to teach the first-years to be ready for magick attacks, should they come. All seventh-years were pranked when it was their turn, and were constantly reminded of the penalty of going too far.

"Where do we start?" Interrupting my thoughts, Cire asked.

"We start with your walk." Motioning to her feet, I replied. "Both boys and girls alike have an unspoken language in all that they do."

"How do you know this?" Wincing, Cire asked.

"I was taught this when Ma Stone insisted I was a boy." Ruefully, I replied. "I am relearning everything I need to know as a girl, and passing it on to you."

"When a girl walks, she does not sway her hips as much as you are unless she wants a boy's attention." Softly, Tia added. "I learned that from Dad... relax your stride a little, and you won't get as many looks."

"I- I'll try." Uncertain, Cire said. "I just can't get used to this... breeze under the skirt."

"That's what leggings are for." Calmly, I said. "I think I have a fresh pair I can give you until you can get to the school store."

Cire sighed. "Mrs Procter told me that, although I was a boy and could be a boy again, no one here will see or treat me that way."

"Of course." Smiling, Tia said. "You are just as much a girl as Sam and I right now."

We reached our dorm room, where Tia and I led Cire to the vanity. Upon sitting down, she became nervous again. "You're not going to give me a makeover, are you?"

"Not unless you really want one." Smiling, I replied. "I just want to fix your hair, it's all over the place."

"Is hair really that important?" Wincing, Cire asked.

I giggled. "Remember that unspoken language... hair is part of it."

"Is everything a girl does and wears a signal to others?" Worried, Cire asked.

"Some boys like to think so." Smiling, Tia said. "Only the signals we are talking about speak of your neatness, confidence, readiness to be approached for conversation..."

Cire smiled slightly when she realized what I was telling her. "I guess I'm still thinking like a boy..."

Tia and I giggled, and I began to carefully brush out Cire's hair.
1111211211212.title: Cire gets girl lessons.

14.content:
Samantha "Sam" Procter: Main character; 11; reunited with her parents after 8 years
John Scooter: 11; Sam's best friend from before Ravenscroft
Tia Wardwell: 11; Sam's roommate; orphaned, then adopted by Wardwell
Andrew "Andy" Stone: 11; As Anna Stone, kidnapped Sam and raised her as her son; now regressed, given a sex change, and learning to be a witch
Cire Child: 11; Sam's roommate; changed into a girl in a prank war

15.title: Faculty

info.brief_description: Samantha is going to a very exclusive school... a school for witches.
info.description:
This story follows 11-year-old Samantha as she learns the truth about her family, and about being a witch.

Of course, you've gotta have rules:

1) Do not kill the main character.
2) First person, past tense.
3) Keep it PG-13. Nudity, if age-appropriate, is fine. Strong language is okay, but don't overdo it. Sex, if age-appropriate, is okay, but don't go into detail.
4) Pop-culture witches are fictional characters in this story, too. Samantha can't meet Harry Potter, the Halliwell sisters, Sabrina, etc.
5) Check out my other interactives for an idea of how I roll.

With that out of the way, let's begin.
